data.title: Taiwan elects Lai Ching-te, denying Chinaâ€™s hopes for reunification
data.meta_description: The results of the tight, three-way presidential election will resonate far beyond the region.
data.text:
Taiwanese voters have chosen Lai Ching-te, the current vice president, as their new leader. Lai, the favorite, led a tight race in a critical election for the future of the islandâ€™s democracy â€” and his promise to pursue the status quo of resisting reunification with China is likely to frustrate the mainland.

China views Taiwan as a rebellious province, rather than an independent country, and Beijingâ€™s longstanding position is that the two should be reunified. Chinese President Xi Jinping recently described this reunification as a â€œhistorical inevitabilityâ€ in his New Yearâ€™s address.

While Chinaâ€™s official position has been that this reunification â€” something Taiwanese voters overwhelmingly oppose â€” should be accomplished by peaceful means, it has not ruled out using force and has stepped up military and economic pressure on the island. This has alarmed governments and military leaders around the world, given the real possibility that a war over Taiwan could draw in other countries including the United States and devastate the global economy.

Underlining the stakes, a senior Chinese official warned Taiwanese voters this week to make the â€œcorrectâ€ choice, describing the election as a decision between â€œpeace and war, prosperity and decline.â€

China on the ballot

The January 13 election put current Vice President Lai Ching-te, also known as William Lai, of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) against New Taipei City Mayor Hou You-ih of the Kuomintang (KMT), as well as third-party candidate Ko Wen-je, of the Taiwan Peopleâ€™s Party (TPP).

In other places, voters might be debating taxes or social issues or government spending. Those are important for Taiwanese voters too, particularly when it comes to housing and cost of living. But Taiwanese politics hinges on one subject.

â€œEvery election is ultimately about China, which makes the two parties big tents on everything else,â€ Nathan Batto, a professor of political science at Taiwanâ€™s Academia Sinica, told Vox. Supporters of one party â€œmight be for higher taxes or lower taxes, for gay marriage or against it. The fundamental cleavage is China.â€

The KMT is descended from the nationalist party that led mainland China for two decades until retreating to Taiwan after the communist takeover in 1949. The KMT controlled Taiwan as an autocratic, one-party state until the islandâ€™s bumpy transition to democracy in the 1990s.

Though the KMT long presented itself as the legitimate government not only of Taiwan but mainland China, ironically it is now the party that favors maintaining closer economic and political ties with Communist Party-ruled China. The DPP, which has held the presidency since 2016 under President Tsai Ing-wen, argues that Taiwan is too reliant on the mainland and should build closer ties with other international powers. (The more recently founded TPP has tried to forge a middle ground between the two, with mixed success.)

Under Tsai, Taiwan deepened its relationship with the US, securing billions of dollars in new arms deals from Washington. The Tsai administration also experienced the most serious crisis in the Taiwan Strait in years when then-House Speaker Nancy Pelosi visited the island in August 2022. Pelosi was the highest-ranking US official to come to Taiwan since 1997, which prompted China to respond with live-fire military drills around Taiwan while Pelosi was present.

While the current election campaign in Taiwan has been bitter and polarizing, the debate itself takes place between very defined and fairly narrow guardrails.

â€œMore than 80 percent of our people oppose reunification now,â€ said Shen Ming-shih, deputy CEO at the Institute for National Defense and Security Research, a Taiwanese think tank. â€œIf a political party tried to revive the idea, they would be rejected immediately,â€

At the same time, neither party advocates declaring full independence, a highly provocative move that might risk war. In recent debates, the DPPâ€™s Lai has had to defend past statements in which he described himself as a â€œpragmatic worker for Taiwan independence.â€ Nowadays, Lai says he subscribes to President Tsaiâ€™s position that there is no need to formally declare independence since the island â€œis already a sovereign, independent country called the Republic of China.â€ In other words, Taiwan is a de facto independent state, albeit one that is only formally recognized by a handful of small countries.

Lai has argued that the KMTâ€™s embrace of Beijing is actually the more dangerous path, and would put the countryâ€™s hard-fought sovereignty at risk. â€œInstead of countering the communists, they now befriend the communists,â€ he has said.

Even under a KMT government, peaceful relations with the mainland are have never been a given. The last time the KMT was in power, from 2008 to 2016, then-President Ma Ying-jeou took a more conciliatory tone and forged a number of trade deals with China, but Beijing was ultimately disappointed by the public backlash this brief detente provoked in Taiwan. In the years since, China under Xi has become even more authoritarian, widening the political gap with a highly democratic Taiwan.

â€œIt may be that [Beijing has] given up on the idea of achieving unification through winning at Taiwanese domestic politics,â€ Batto said. â€œTheyâ€™re certainly not making any internal compromises to their own positions to build a constituency here.â€

Dialing up the pressure

Shen notes that in years past, Xi often played up the possibility of a â€œone country, two systemsâ€ model for Taiwan, referring to the arrangement by which Hong Kong, when it reverted to Beijingâ€™s control in 1997, was promised a degree of political independence while being formally part of China. But Xiâ€™s recent statements, including both his New Yearâ€™s address and tough remarks about Taiwan during a recent meeting with President Joe Biden, showed the Chinese leaderâ€™s â€œdetermination to accomplish reunification.â€ And the promise of â€œone country, two systemsâ€ lost all credibility after Beijing-backed authorities cracked down on Hong Kongâ€™s democratic opposition in 2021.

The trendlines in Taiwanese politics are certainly not heading Chinaâ€™s way. According to recent polls, 66 percent of the population now identifies as solely Taiwanese, as opposed to 28 percent as both Taiwanese and Chinese and just 4 percent as solely Chinese. (Notably, only 2.3 percent of Taiwanâ€™s population is Indigenous, and not ethnically Chinese.) This trend is particularly pronounced among younger Taiwanese, including those whose grandparents or great-grandparents fled communist China.

While thereâ€™s still significant trade across the Taiwan Strait, and Taiwanese companies like iPhone-maker FoxConn are major players in the mainland economy, the number of Taiwanese workers in mainland China has been falling steadily in recent years. And while military tensions between the two are hardly new, Chinaâ€™s growing military and economic power has allowed it to dial up the pressure in recent years.

This pressure campaign has included flying an increasing number of military aircraft into airspace around the island, sometimes up to dozens in a day. Taiwanese officials have also claimed the government faces millions of cyberattacks per month, with about half of them believed to originate in China.

China has also used diplomatic pressure and financial inducements to encourage the remaining countries that have formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan to drop them and recognize Beijing. Nine countries have dropped their recognition of Taiwan since Tsai came to power in 2016. Just 13 countries remain, most of them small island states in the Pacific or Caribbean.

China still has ways to dial up that pressure further, including interfering with trade, either through a full blockade or by pressuring companies to avoid shipping to an island that is highly dependent on imports of food and energy.

â€œChinaâ€™s strategy has long been to try and erode the confidence of the people of Taiwan and and induce a sense of psychological despair,â€ said Glaser. The hope in Beijing, Glaser says, is that Taiwanâ€™s population will reluctantly conclude that â€œthe best future is one in which they are part of China in some way.â€

The toll of war

Thatâ€™s how Chinaâ€™s wait-it-out strategy might work. But there is also the disturbing possibility that Xi, or one of his successors, could lose patience with Taiwanese intransigence.

Xi has said repeatedly that the task of reunification should not be â€œpassed on from generation to generation.â€ During his recent summit meeting with Biden, Xi emphasized that he was still committed to peaceful reunification but, according to US officials who were present, â€œmoved immediately to conditions that the potential use of force could be utilized.â€ Former US Indo-Pacific commander Adm. Phil Davidson suggested in congressional testimony in 2021 that China is likely to move on Taiwan â€œin the next six years.â€

Such a war, if it did come, could make the Russian invasion of Ukraine look small by comparison. Some analysts have suggested an invading force of 1 million to 2 million troops might be necessary. The war could involve the United States, as well. Under whatâ€™s known as the â€œone-China policy,â€ the US technically recognizes Taiwan as part of China and doesnâ€™t have formal diplomatic relations with Taipei. But in practice, Washington has become Taiwanâ€™s most important political backer and supplier of military equipment.

The US hasnâ€™t made clear as an official matter of policy whether it would come to Taiwanâ€™s aid if the island were attacked, a stance known as â€œstrategic ambiguity.â€ But President Biden has said on three separate occasions that the US has a commitment to defend Taiwan, and though the White House walked back these statements each time, growing tensions between Washington and Beijing may make US involvement more likely. Many analyses of a potential conflict have suggested that China might even preemptively strike US bases in the Pacific to hamper the American response.

The human toll of such a war would be staggering. A recent wargame by the Center for Strategic and International Studies found that while a US-led international force, presumably including East Asian allies like Japan, could defeat the Chinese military in a conflict over Taiwan, in just three weeks of fighting, the US could lose half as many troops as in 20 years of fighting in Iraq and Afghanistan. In the CSIS scenario, the US was projected to lose two aircraft carriers and 10 to 20 large surface ships â€” the kind of losses not seen since World War II. And this is even without taking into account Chinaâ€™s growing nuclear arsenal.

While the fighting would likely be contained around Taiwan, the economic impact of a war, or even just a full-scale Chinese blockade of the island, would be felt worldwide. Taiwanâ€™s dominant company, TSMC, produces the microchips used in nearly all the worldâ€™s smartphones, about a third of its personal computers, and myriad other devices. Should these highly sophisticated factories suffer major damage or be destroyed in the course of an invasion, â€œweâ€™d face an economic crisis globally akin to the disruptions that we saw during the Great Depression,â€ as Chris Miller, author of the book Chip War, said on The Ezra Klein Show last year.

The worldâ€™s reliance on these chips is so great that it has sometimes been called Taiwanâ€™s â€œsilicon shield.â€ The idea is that the global economy, very much including China itself, is simply too reliant on Taiwan-made semiconductors to risk any action that might take the supply offline. But as the invasion of Ukraine has shown, countries can be willing to incur severe economic costs to accomplish what they see as major geopolitical goals â€” and reunification is about as fundamental as it gets for China.

Of course, the costs borne by the world pale in relation to those that would be felt by Taiwan in an invasion scenario.

â€œInternationally, a lot of people look at Ukraine as an inspirational story of resisting aggression and the encroachment of a foreign power,â€ said Batto. â€œBut here, we see apartment blocks [in Ukraine] being bombed and think, â€˜That could be my house.â€™â€

Update, January 13, 11:24 am ET: This story was originally published on January 6, and has been updated multiple times, most recently to include results of the Taiwan presidential election.

Correction, January 8, 9:30 am ET: A previous version of this story misstated the city that Hou You-ih is mayor of. It is New Taipei City.
